text: while historians might look back on 2008
as two-year Wall Street tense resilient
New Yorkers and trend seeking visitors
may remember it as the year that
everything old became new again
to spend a great weekend in the new New
York start with a casual walk through
the Lower East Side's thriving art scene
stop in at brand-new gallery 9/5 where
owner sebastian lapel da
houses a collection ranging from tribal
art to work by contemporary artists as
dinner time approaches make your way to
the Meatpacking District where Scarpetta
is refined take on Italian food raise
the hip neighborhoods
julen are a profile when it opens back
in May after cab uptown for a nightcap
Peninsula hotel's rooftop bar salon
Denis the Chinese day beds may look
alluring but get a table nearer to the
balconies edge in order to take in the
nighttime views
begin the next day with brunch at my
condo chef Maximo Sahara brings pan
Latin dishes inspired by street foods
it was setting the bursts with downtown
energy after a long leisurely meal head
north to Columbus Circle
in September the museum formerly known
as the American crafts museum reopened
in the revamped - Columbus Circle
building with a new grandeur named the
Museum of Arts and Design
check out the hands-on artist studios or
exhibitions like second lives works from
contemporary artists who turn common
objects like eyeglasses and records into
art all that walking will work up your
appetite so treat yourself to dinner in
Tribeca
at John George von Guericke ins latest
venture Matt sugan no reservation is
required to order the freshly made soba
noodle dishes most of which are under
$20 if you land a table facing the fish
tanks you'll enjoy an aquatic view of
your food being prepared after dinner
ditch Manhattan for Brooklyn grab a
quick cocktail at humble Hills
old-school but very new clover club and
then catch some live music at the Bell
House in the still very industrial
Gowanus area
whatever is new in the city it's not
worth getting up early on a Sunday sleep
till noon then hit up five napkin burger
the June opening of this Hell's Kitchen
spot showed that New Yorkers appetites
for upscale burgers did not level off in
and your adventure in the new New York
by taking in some laughs at Broadway's
Longacre theater where a revival of
Boeing Boeing opened in May the Tony
award-winning comedy about an American
man in Paris juggling affairs with free
flight attendants thrilled audiences and
critics quite an improvement considering
the original 1965 run closed after a
mere 23 performances it's time to head
home and tell your friends about
everything old that's become new in the
city just hurry up before all that new
stuff becomes old
